:accompanier: Example: "The mayor arrived with a police escort ."
:age: Example: "Pierre Vinken , 61 years old , will join the board as a nonexecutive director Nov. 29 ."
:beneficiary: Example: "My friend recorded a song for me ."
:cause: cause-01 is used for explicit words such as cause/because/because of
as well implicit cases such as in the first example below (cause of death).
Example: "The old man died of lung cancer ."
Example: "Cars ca n't move because of overflowing sewers ."
The editor offers :cause as a shortcut for :ARG1-of cause-01 :ARG0.
:concession: the concession-event creates an expectation which is at least
partially invalidated by the main-event. The expectation can be
In English, a concession-event is typically signalled by the

subordinating conjunctions <font color="blue">al<font color="blue">though</font></font>, <font color="blue">even <font color="blue">though</font></font>, <font color="blue">though</font>, and <font color="blue">albeit</font>,
or the prepositions <font color="blue">despite</font>, <font color="blue"><font color="blue">despite</font> of</font> and <font color="blue">in spite of</font>.
It can also be signalled on the main-event side by adverbs
such as <font color="blue">however</font> and <font color="blue">nevertheless</font>, or even by the conjunction <font color="blue">but</font>,
particularly when <font color="blue">but</font> is used in conjunction with <font color="blue">anyway</font>.
Example: The game continued although it rained .
Example: The game continued despite of the rain .
Example: It started to rain, but the game continued anyway .
<li> It started to rain; <font color="blue">but</font> the game continued .
<li> It started to rain; <font color="blue">but</font> the game continued <font color="blue">anyway</font> .
<li> It started to rain; <font color="blue">however</font>, the game continued .
<li> It started to rain; <font color="blue">nevertheless</font>, the game continued .
Example: Workers described `` clouds of blue dust '' that hung over parts of the factory , even though exhaust fans ventilated the area .
:condition: The role <font color="red">:condition</font> is used for <font color="blue">if</font>, <font color="blue">unless</font>, and <font color="blue">in case of</font>.
Example: The game will be canceled if it rains .
Example: In the case of rain, the game will be canceled .
For negative conditionals such as <font color="blue">unless</font>, include :polarity -
Example: The game will be canceled unless the rain stops .
:consist-of: The role <font color="red">:consist-of</font> is used to describe what substance or which members something is made of:
Similarly: a puddle of water, a loaf of bread
Example: "A team of researchers made a discovery ."
Similarly: a flock of birds, a convoy of trucks
:cost: The frame <font color="red">cost-01</font> is not only used for explicit occurrences of <font color="blue">to cost</font>, but also implied cost relationships.
The editor offers :cost as a shortcut for :ARG1-of cost-01 :ARG0.
:degree: <li> Use <font color="red">have-degree-91</font> (or <font color="red">have-quant-91</font>) for <font color="blue">comparatives</font> and <font color="blue">superlatives</font>

<li> Use <font color="red">have-degree-91</font> (or <font color="red">have-quant-91</font>) for <font color="blue">consequence constructions</font> with <font color="red">too</font> / <font color="red">enough</font> / <font color="red">so</font>
<li> It is <font color="red">too</font> early to reach any conclusions.
<li> This computer is small <font color="red">enough</font> to fit in your pocket.
<li> He was <font color="red">so</font> tired that he slept for 10 hours.
<li> Use <font color="red">:degree</font> for <font color="blue">intensifiers</font> and <font color="blue">downtoners</font>.
<li> <font color="red">What</font> a great book!           <font color="#777777">= <font color="red">so</font> great a book</font>
<li> <font color="red">How</font> beautiful you are.     <font color="#777777">= You are <font color="red">so</font> beautiful!</font>
Example: "the girl is taller than the boy"
Example: It is too early to reach any conclusions.
Example: The car is much too expensive.
Example: This computer is small enough to fit in your pocket.
Example: He was so tired that he slept for 10 hours.
Example: We entered the cave at noon and left it 2 hours later.
:destination: Example: "He drove west, from Houston to Austin ."
Example: "She heated the oven to 250 degrees Celsius ."
:direction: We use the role <font color="red">:direction</font> for directions of the compass such as <font color="blue">north</font> and <font color="blue">south</font>,

as well as for <font color="blue">up</font> and <font color="blue">down</font>, <font color="blue">left</font> and <font color="blue">right</font>, <font color="blue">back</font> and <font color="blue">forth</font>, and <font color="blue">towards</font> a place.
When an argument is a :source or a :destination,
we do not also mark it as a direction.
Example: He drove west, from Houston to Austin .
Example: The plane crash occurred 50 miles east of Moscow.
Example: We drove 5 miles towards the coast.
Example: He drove away from the sunset.
Example: I commute back and forth to work on the Huguenot Trail.
Related roles: :source (from starting point), :destination (to end point), :path (a path or places on a path)
:domain: This role is used in constructions such as ... is <noun> and ... is <adjective>:
If there is a specific frame for an adjective, such as for possible, use that frame and its :ARGx instead.
The role :domain is also used under modal concepts such as likely:
:employed-by: The old role :employed-by is now superceded by have-org-role-91.
For explicit mentions of employ, we continue to use the frames employ-01
Shortcut: :employed-by and :role can be used as shortcuts for have-org-role-91,
Example: "A Lorillard spokewoman said , `` This is an old story ."
:example: Example: high tech companies like IBM and Google
:frequency: When the frequency relationship is modified, use its reification <font color="red">have-frequency-91</font>:
Events that occur with regular <font color="red">:frequency</font> are annotated using <font color="blue">rate-entity-91</font>:
:instrument: <font color="red">:instrument</font> describes the physical object used in an action, typically a tool, device, weapon, or a body part such as a <font color="blue">finger</font> or fist.
If you want to more generally describe how or in what way something is done, then consider using :manner instead.
Example: I ate pasta with a fork .
Example: He ate the pizza with his fingers.
Example: He recovered the frisbee with a long stick.
Make sure you use any core role <font color="red">:ARGx</font> designated for instruments, if available:
Example: He caught the fish with a net.
:li: The role :li (for list item) is used to mark numbers or letters in lists such as:
<li> <font color="blue">(1)</font> Germany <font color="blue">(2)</font> Brazil <font color="blue">(3)</font> Italy <font color="blue">(4)</font> Argentina
<li> <font color="blue">(A)</font> Jimmy Carter <font color="blue">(B)</font> Ronald Reagan <font color="blue">(C)</font> George Bush <font color="blue">(D)</font> Bill Clinton
It is also used for ordinals such as <font color="blue">first</font>, <font color="blue">second</font> etc. in multi-sentence lists as in:
<li> The political candidate promises all of the following.
<font color="blue">First</font>, to create 2 million new jobs.
<font color="blue">Second</font>, to cut income tax rates by 10%.
<font color="blue">Fourth</font>, to hire 100,000 more police officers.
Example: First, what is the biggest puzzle between China and the US?
Similarly: row 7, bus 20, group A, appendix B
:location: Example: "The plane crash occurred 50 miles east of Moscow."
Example: "26 of the 44 countries in Europe are members of NATO."
:manner: including methods to do something (or "means") and modes of transportation.
However, use the more specific roles
Example: "He decorated the room in a creative way."
Example: "The company obtained the permit through bribery."
Example: "The mayor proposed to lower crime by hiring more police officers."
Example: "Lindbergh crossed the Atlantic in the Spirit of St. Louis."
:mean: <font color="red">mean-01</font> is used when the meaning of a term or phrase is explained to the user,
even if the word mean is not explicitly mentioned in the text.
Such an explanation can be in the form of a definition. Another example
is when a legalese term or sentence is then explained in plain English.
The added meaning does not strictly add information to the sentence.
Example: "He replied to her with a flame (a hostile and insulting email)."
The editor offers :meaning as a shortcut for :ARG0-of mean-01 :ARG1.
:medium: Examples of typical <font color="red">:medium</font> entities include radio, television, newspaper, <font color="blue">web</font>, Facebook, <font color="blue">Twitter</font>, languages.
Example: The mayor announced his resignation on Twitter .
Example: The new book has been heavily advertised on the web .
Example: She talked to him in French.
:mod: <font color="red">:mod</font> stands for an unspecified modifier, often when modifying a noun:
Example: "The old man died of lung cancer ."
:mode: Use <font color="red">:mode</font> <font color="red">interrogative</font> to mark a yes-no question.
The role <font color="red">:mode</font> is also used for imperatives:
Finally, the role <font color="red">:mode</font> is used to express some emotions, which do not
have the primary function of conveying information, ask a question
(<font color="red">:mode</font> <font color="red">interrogative</font>) or order (<font color="red">:mode</font> <font color="red">imperative</font>).
Note that "Yes." as a normal answer to a question is not marked with
any <font color="red">:mode</font>, as it plainly conveys information based on the preceding
question. But a celebratory "Yes!!!" after your favorite sports team
scores an imporant point should be marked up using <font color="red">:mode</font> <font color="red">expressive</font>.
Use <font color="red">amr-unknown</font> as a concept to indicate the target of a question.
:name: The role <font color="red">:name</font> is used for named entities:
Example: "Steven Spielberg lives in Los Angeles ."
<span class="amrpenman">
(l / live-01
:ARG0 (p / person :wiki "Steven_Spielberg"
<font color="red">:name</font> (n / name :op1 "Steven" :op2 "Spielberg"))
:location (c / city :wiki "Los_Angeles"
<font color="red">:name</font> (n2 / name :op1 "Los" :op2 "Angeles")))
Example: "The USS Iowa passed under the Golden Gate Bridge ."
<span class="amrpenman">
(p / pass-02
:ARG0 (s / ship :wiki "USS_Iowa_(BB-61)"
<font color="red">:name</font> (n / name :op1 "USS" :op2 "Iowa"))
:ARG1 (u / under
:op1 (b / bridge :wiki "Golden_Gate_Bridge"
<font color="red">:name</font> (n2 / name :op1 "Golden" :op2 "Gate" :op3 "Bridge"))))
More on named entities.
:ord: • When Not to Use :ord for first or last
An ordinal number defines a thing's position in a series, e.g. <font color="blue">first</font>, <font color="blue">second</font>, or <font color="blue">third</font>.
We use the role <font color="red">:ord</font> and the corresponding cardinal number (1, 2, 3) to express an ordinal.
Ordinals can be qualified (e.g. <font color="blue">first</font> in 10 years), so we include a concept <font color="red">ordinal-entity</font>
to accommodate both the primary value as well as any qualifications.
Note: In the AMR Editor, you can just type in p :ord 2
Example: He was the first to do this.
Example: When I met her for the first time, Mary still worked for Goldman Sachs.
As an alternative to a simple value, AMR also also offers a value-interval, including an open interval:
For expressions such as "second to last", AMR uses a negative ordinal value:
Example: We sat in the preantepenultimate pew.
Example combining an ordinal and a superlative
Example: Texas is the second largest state in the U.S.
However, we don't use ordinals for plain superlatives, i.e. is :ord (o / ordinal-entity :value 1) is understood as a default.
But don't use :ord for "fuzzy ordinals" such as:
Example: Canada is one of the largest countries in the world.
Example: Canada and the U.S. are among the largest countries in the world.
But do not use :ord for last in the sense of previous
as in "I bought a new car last week." or for first in the
sense of initially as in "I first had to get used to it."
:part: The role <font color="red">:part</font> is used for physical parts of physical objects.
It's also used to specify parts of countries and other geopolitical entities,
such as the <font color="blue">south</font> of France, or <font color="blue">mainland</font> China.
Example: They live in the south of France.
:path: We use the role <font color="red">:path</font> for paths as well places on a path on which an object moves,
including rivers, roads and tunnels; towns (driven through) and facilities (passed by).
Example: "I threw the stone across the river."
Related roles: :source (from starting point), :destination (to end point), :direction (north, up, left, towards)
:polarity: Example: "There is no possibility that the boy will go."
:polite: Example: Would you kindly close the door?
Example: Could you tell me what time it is?
However, :polite + is not used for any sentence just because it is polite:
• You are a wonderful cook. Do not use :polite + for mere compliments.
• It was not the most accessible textbook I have read. (= It was incredibly confusing.) Do not use :polite + for euphemisms.
:poss: The role <font color="red">:poss</font> ("possessed by") is a very general form of possession.
Often used with possessive pronouns, as well as of and 's.
:purpose: Use <font color="red">:purpose</font> only when <font color="blue">:cause</font> is not appropriate.
Example: "He went to the store to buy wood for a new fence ."
:source: Example: "He drove west, from Houston to Austin ."
Example: "The boy met a girl from Spain ."
:subevent: Example: "In the 1974 soccer World Cup final, Germany beat the Netherlands 2-1."
:subset: The frame <font color="red">include-91</font> describes a <font color="blue">subset/superset</font> relationship. <font color="red">include-91</font> is often
used without any occurrence or the verb <font color="blue">to include</font> in the sentence.
Example: "10% of smokers die of lung cancer."
Example: "Thomas is one of the few boys in Kentucky who speak Latin ."
Example: "26 of the 44 countries in Europe are members of NATO."
The AMR Editor offers :subset as a shortcut for :ARG2-of include-91 :ARG1.
:superset: The frame <font color="red">include-91</font> describes a <font color="blue">subset/superset</font> relationship. <font color="red">include-91</font> is often
used without any occurrence or the verb <font color="blue">to include</font> in the sentence.
Example: "10% of smokers die of lung cancer."
Example: "Thomas is one of the few boys in Kentucky who speak Latin ."
Example: "26 of the 44 countries in Europe are members of NATO."
The AMR Editor offers :subset as a shortcut for :ARG2-of include-91 :ARG1.
:time: The role <font color="red">:time</font> is used for two purposes:
• for a general event, to capture when the event happened (or will happen)
• within the context of a date-entity, the specific time in 24-hour notation such as "18:00"
Example: "America was discovered several hundred years ago."
Click here for more examples such as
<li> in the last three years   (= during the 3 years after now)
<li> during the next two years   (= during the 2 years before now)
<li> in the two months after the murder (= during the 2 years after the murder)
:topic: Example: "There is no information about the case ."
:value: Used in entities such as percentage-entity, email-address-entity, url-entity, phone-number-entity,
where it fully describes the entity of a given type:
:timezone: Official timezones are annotated as strings:
<font color="blue">Local</font> and inofficial timezones are annotated using concepts:
Example: eight o'clock in the morning local time
See also general examples for date entities.
:calendar: The role <font color="red">:calendar</font> is used for the calendars of various cultures:
<li> <font color="blue">Gregorian</font> calendar (modern Western, de facto international standard)
<li> <font color="blue">Julian</font> calendar (old Western, differs from <font color="blue">Gregorian</font> calendar in which years are leap <nobr>y</nobr>ears)
<li> <font color="blue">Islamic</font> calendar (lunar calendar; 1 AH = 622 AD, 1434 AH = Nov. 14, 2012 to Nov. 4, 2013)
<li> <font color="blue">Hebrew</font> calendar (lunisolar calendar = lunar calendar with leap months; 5773 AM = Sept. 16, 2012 - Sept. 4, 2013)
The role <font color="red">:calendar</font> is also used for <nobr>y</nobr>ears that differ from the standard calendar <nobr>y</nobr>ear.
In these cases, the concept <font color="blue">year</font> is included:
Example: The 9.3 Tohoku earthquake occured in the year Heisei 23 .
See also general examples for date entities.
:era: The role <font color="red">:era</font> is used for calendar eras, including regnal eras.
In the Japanese calendar, eras correspond to the reigns of Japanese emperors: Meiji (1868-1912), Taisho (1912-1926), Showa (1926-1989), <font color="blue">Heisei</font> (since 1989)
Example: Three Roman legions were annihilated in the Battle of the Teutoburg Forest in 9 AD .
Example: The 9.3 Tohoku earthquake occured in the year Heisei 23 .
Note: The Japanese year <font color="blue">Heisei</font> 23 corresponds to the year 2011 in the Western calendar.
DO NOT use :era for geological eras (such as the Mesozoic Era) or colloquial eras (such as the Victorian Era).
See also general examples for date entities.

See also more specific examples for

(d / date-entity <font color="red">:month</font> 2 <font color="red">:day</font> 29 <font color="red">:year</font> 2012 <font color="red">:time</font> "16:30" <font color="red">:timezone</font> "PST"
See also more specific examples for

(d / date-entity <font color="red">:month</font> 2 <font color="red">:day</font> 29 <font color="red">:year</font> 2012 <font color="red">:time</font> "16:30" <font color="red">:timezone</font> "PST"
See also more specific examples for

(d / date-entity <font color="red">:month</font> 2 <font color="red">:day</font> 29 <font color="red">:year</font> 2012 <font color="red">:time</font> "16:30" <font color="red">:timezone</font> "PST"
